title: These pandas are Canadian. So why are they moving to China?
text:
Although still vulnerable, giant pandas no longer endangered

It’s time for Calgary’s twin giant pandas to leave the nest.

Bamboo nest, to be exact.

At four years old, Jian Panpan, a male, and Jia Yueyue, a female, are old enough to leave their parents and head out on their own.

For giant pandas — a species that was considered endangered for 26 years — that means flying all the way back to China to take part in a breeding program.

Good news for the health of the species but bad news for the record-breaking crowds that have been watching the pandas grow up — first at the Toronto Zoo then the Calgary Zoo — since their birth in Canada in 2015.

Let’s face it, who doesn’t love to watch pandas in action? Or even inaction, for that matter.

"Even when they're sleeping, they look cute," said Cissy Kou, zookeeper at the Calgary Zoo.

Four giant pandas have been living at the Calgary Zoo since 2018: a mother, father and twin cubs. (Martin Trainor/CBC)

All giant pandas born outside of China eventually have to move there to take part in a program that helps them reproduce.

Giant pandas were moved off the endangered list and onto the vulnerable list in 2016, following a push to restore their habitat and bring the species back from the brink.

There are around 1,900 giant pandas left on the planet, according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature’s red list of threatened species.

That’s around 650 more than there were back in the 1980s.

The black and white bears are considered an umbrella species, meaning that by protecting them, we’re also protecting a whole bunch of other species that live in the same environment.

The four giant pandas at the Calgary Zoo eat around 1,100 kilograms of bamboo each week, which has to be flown in from China. (Nelly Alberola/CBC)

Not to worry, panda fans, it’s possible the Calgary Zoo may have another baby panda in the mix soon.

The twins’ mother, Er Shun, might be pregnant again.

“Nothing is guaranteed,” Kou said. “She is showing that she might be, but we don’t know.”

If there is a new cub on the way, it won’t get the chance to meet its brother and sister.

The twins are expected to board a plane for Chengdu, China, sometime after Oct. 6.

But first, the Calgary Zoo is hosting a farewell party from 10 a.m. MT to 2 p.m. MT from Oct. 4-6.

If you live out of province, you can livestream the whole family as they say their goodbyes on this handy dandy panda cam.

Here’s how panda twins Jia Panpan and Jia Yueyue looked when they were five-month-old cubs living at the Toronto Zoo in 2016. (Chris Young/The Canadian Press)

With files from Jennifer Dorozio/CBC Calgary, The Associated Press
description: Why Canadians are preparing to say goodbye to twin panda cubs who’ve been living at the Calgary Zoo and are heading back to China.
